data.title: Venezuela has officially annexed the disputed territory of Guyana-Essequibo by passing legislation creating a new state.
data.meta_description: The Venezuelan authorities have included the territory of Guyana-Essequibo, disputed with neighboring Guyana, into the country. The country's legislature adopted a law that gives Essequibo the rights of the 24th state of Venezuela. Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro, speaking on national television
data.text:
The Venezuelan authorities have included the territory of Guyana-Essequibo, disputed with neighboring Guyana, into the country. The country's legislature adopted a law that gives Essequibo the rights of the 24th state of Venezuela.

Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro, speaking on national television, said that residents of the state will be able to participate in parliamentary elections in the country as early as 2025. In addition, it was decided to create a Commission for the Protection of a new state.

Now in Venezuela it is possible to issue maps of the country only with the inclusion of the state of Guyana-Essequibo. The work of new structures of the oil and gas company PDVSA, the Venezuelan Corporation of Guyana, and the country's law enforcement agencies will be regulated in the state.

History disputes over the Guyana-Essequibo territory go back to the 1824th century. The debate has been going on since XNUMX. This territory is claimed by Venezuela and Guyana (formerly British Guiana). Now these disputes have become topical due to the fact that large oil reserves have been discovered in the region.

Guyana cannot assert its claims to the region by force without outside help, since its armed forces are not comparable to Venezuela’s. Caracas, in turn, views the annexation of the new territory as the restoration of historical justice and the continuation of the struggle for national sovereignty and the assertion of national political and economic interests.

Venezuelan President Maduro also said that in the territory of Guyana-Essequibo there are secret bases of the US Central Intelligence Agency (CIA) and the US Southern Command. Now the region, he said, is controlled by the Southern Command, the CIA and the American oil company ExxonMobil. This is being done in order for American companies to seize control over the natural resources of the region. The American presence is a serious obstacle for Venezuela in establishing its control over the new territory.

Wikipedia / Cancillería del Ecuador - https://www.flickr.com
